body: There's a bug in how prompt-toolkit handles TERM being undefined, but I suspect there might be another issue. cc @jonathanslenders for ideas.

Hi @zhuyuxing, the error message has been fixed in this commit: https://github.com/jonathanslenders/python-prompt-toolkit/commit/99fa7fae61c9b4ed9767ead3b4f9b1318cfa875d

However, this happens during the error handling of another issue.
I guess that you are not starting IPython from cmd.exe, is that possible?

Hi @jonathanslenders ,Thank you for your solution, but  I'm sure I start IPython from cmd.exe.

I edited the code in prompt_toolkit/terminal/win32_output.py according your solution, the error is that your said "prompt_toolkit.terminal.win32_output.NoConsoleScreenBufferError: No Windows cons
ole found. Are you running cmd.exe?".

Also, I tried to test them in virtualenv.
when I ran IPython from python27 in virtualenv, then pip install ipython, and it hadn't any error and ran it successfully.
when I ran IPython from python34 in virtualenv with no packages, then pip install ipython, but it happened the same error again.

I have no idea for it, I guess I will test it in my home using another computer, just want to know if this current computer  has any problem.

I think I have solved it though I don't know the reason. I pip install python4, then the error doesn't happen again.

My ipython version is ipython5. When I ran pycharm to use python3.4 console, it got an error: 'PyDevTerminalInteractiveShell' object has no attribute 'has_readline'
then I internet the error to solve it, and someone solved it :  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/38341240/pydevterminalinteractiveshell-object-has-no-attribute-has-readline.

When I changed my ipython5 to ipython4, the error doesn't happen again.

I too have this same issue. Running pip install for IPython didn't work for version 4 as well. I had to manually install IPython and the various dependencies. I have Windows 10 and ran pip install for version 5.0 from the command line
That's a different error, and looking at the Jetbrains issue tracker, it should be fixed if you upgrade Pycharm to 2016.2.

@takluyver @jonathanslenders @minrk @ouverz @zhuyuxing 

Hi all, brought here by [Code Triage](https://www.codetriage.com/). I am making a public commitment to seeing this random issue through to a satisfactory resolution! I hope I can count on your support in this endeavour.

Does this issue still merit investigation? If so, could you please confirm if I can (most likely) reproduce this issue by fulfilling the following dependencies/environment:

- Windows ( @ouverz mentions Windows 10? )
- Virtualenv
- Python 3.4
- iPython (version 5?)

The original error reported has been fixed in prompt_toolkit. There was another issue with PyCharm described above which has been fixed in PyCharm. And there was a third issue (`NoConsoleScreenBufferError`) related to prompt_toolkit in Windows, but I don't think we've ever had a reliable way to replicate that - prompt_toolkit usually works in Windows, and we haven't identified any pattern in people reporting issues with it. There may also have been upgrades to prompt_toolkit which fixed it in the meantime.

If you have a Windows computer, then feel free to install and launch it in different ways and see if you can replicate the issue.

The ``NoConsoleScreenError`` is probably fixed as well. (See: https://github.com/jonathanslenders/python-prompt-toolkit/commit/d5d9e29 ). I'm not 100% sure, because this only happened on certain installations of Windows in a particular situation, and it was hard to reproduce. But I haven't heard of anyone having that issues for some time.

In a situation like this, we'd probably close the issue normally and suggest people file a new one if they can still reproduce a similar error. There's no special protocol for that, though.

As you were preparing to try to replicate it, let's leave it open until you've had a go. If you can replicate it, we can attempt to work out what's going on; if not, we'll close the issue.

@takluyver I took my sweet ass time but I finally have an environment set up to try reproducing this issue.

I'm running Windows 10, and I have replicated the original issuers Python settings:

```
Python 3.4.0 (v3.4.0:04f714765c13, Mar 16 2014, 19:25:23) [MSC v.1600 64 bit (AMD64)]
Type "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.

IPython 5.1.0 -- An enhanced Interactive Python.
```

I now face a different Prompt Toolkit error:

```

```

Here are some issues with similar errors:

https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/10070
https://github.com/jonathanslenders/python-prompt-toolkit/issues/406

What could I have missed in my setup? Perhaps something to do with my unfamiliarity with windows.

Hi @aaronmyatt,

Is it possible that you are running IPython from within git-bash or something similar instead of cmd.exe?
If so, it will probably work using winpty, but better is to use a real console.
